answers.answer: Hello,It can be due to meralgia parasthetica or parasthesia. Parasthesias are common in alcoholics and metabolic disorders like diabetes, hypothyroidism, and hypoparathyroidismThey can also be due to peripheral vascular disease, vitamin B12 deficiency or malnutrition.Get your blood sugar and thyroid hormones levels evaluated. You can take some vit B12 for some days and see if the tingling is gone or not.In case the symptoms persist then please consult a neurologist as it can be due to some neurological disorder. I hope it helps. Take care and regards.

question: I am currently experiencing a burning/road rash like sensation on my inner and top of thigh.  There are no visible signs of anything- redness etc...  I am almost convinced its some sort of nerve issue.  Like something is lieing to my nerves saying there is a problem in the affected area, when theres not.  While browsing the internet, I have become aware of the conditon called  meralgia paresthetica.  The symptoms I have read that are associated with it are tingling, numbness and burning.  But I do not feel tingling or numbness- just burning.  The burning sensation is constant; meaning everytime my pants material slightly touch my skin or if my other leg touches the inside of my right (affected) thigh.  The pain is from any slight contact with the area.  Firm pressure does not actually hurt, only a light touch.  This is on my right thigh only. Top and inner, from mid-thigh to the knee.  I will add that I have experienced this before.  The first time was about 3-4 years ago, and it lasted for apprx. 1 month.  Then it happened last year, again for about 1 month.  It has been going on currently for about 1 week.  It is driving me crazy more than anything.  I feel that I should let whoever's reading this know that I also have Hashimoto's Hypothroidism.  Which I have heard can be associated with meralgia paresthetica (in what way or what level I dont know).  Could this be meralgia paresthetica or something else I have not heard of?  Again- No visible symptoms (nor will there be, I know by now).  Thanks for reading this- I hope somebody has some great ideas.  I have attatched a photo outlining the area.Sincerely, Frank
title: Burning thigh sensation.
